learning_outcomes.description: Analyse relevant information about economic and business problems, and apply mathematical methods from Operations Research and Management Science to create models for them.
Synthesise relevant information about economic and business problems, and solve mathematical models analytically to identify optimal solutions and perform sensitivity analysis.

Analyse and synthesise relevant information about economic and business problems and use computer software to formulate and solve mathematical models in Operations Research and Management Science, conducting sensitivity analysis as part of the process.
Analyse, synthesise, and evaluate the results of these estimations, effectively communicating the findings and their underlying logic through various digital communication and presentation tools.

assessments.due_date: These quizzes will be held during and at the tutorials (in person mode) of Weeks 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12.
assessments.category: Computer Code, Practical/ Demonstration, Quiz, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
These Weekly Quizzes are to be done by each student individually, in person only, during and at the Tutorials to which the student is officially signed up. 

These quizzes will be held during Weeks 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12 (unless explicitly announced otherwise by the course coordinator via the blackboard). Best seven (out of the total nine weekly quizzes) will count towards the final grade.

Each quiz will be made available via Blackboard. (You must work in isolation while completing the quiz. Any direct or indirect collusion with others during this time may lead to charges of academic misconduct and a mark of zero for this assessment task.) 

Each quiz involves multiple choice questions that generally need to be answered based on the material from prior lectures and tutorials. It will require analytic (mathematical) formulations of a business problem and computations and involving a use of the software or/and an interpretation of its output.  It may also request submission of workings (e.g., as screenshots from the spreadsheet or a photo of derivations on the paper, etc.) The typical timing is about 20 minutes, typically at the beginning of the designated tutorial. The tutorial of Week 2 will have a trial quiz.

Note: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of any generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools is not permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Electronically via Blackboard, in person, in the tutorial room.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date: Due during and at the Tutorial of Week 13.
assessments.task_description:
This Test is to be done in person, individually, during and at the Tutorial of Week 13. It will be made available via Blackboard. (You must work in isolation while completing the Test. Any direct or indirect collusion with others during this time may lead to charges of academic misconduct and a mark of zero for this assessment task.) The test involves multiple choice questions that generally need to be answered based on the material from lectures and tutorials of Weeks 1-12, and may require solving problems via analytic (mathematical) formulations, derivations and computations and involving a use of the software or/and an interpretation of its output.  More information regarding the structure of the test and how to prepare for it will be provided in lectures and/or Blackboard announcements in the weeks leading up to the test.

The students can prepare better for this test by answering the quiz questions during the lectures (in-person only) when these questions are prompted randomly by the lecturer. About 2-3 minutes will be given for answering each question. Note that these questions are similar to those that will be during the comprehensive test.

Note: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of any generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools is not permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Electronically via Blackboard, in person, in the tutorial room.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Creative Production/ Exhibition, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Project
assessments.task_description:
Project Guidelines will be posted on the Blackboard.

The project will require for the student to state the research problem (or a case study) that will need to be solved via analytic (mathematical) formulations, derivations and computations with a software (e.g., Excel QM or other software presented during Lectures or Tutorials). Project report must be presented in a tidy business-style report complemented with two videos (10-minute video and 1-minute video) explaining the work and results obtained by the student.

Note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to OR & MS; Optimization and Math Programming

Operations Research (OR) & Management Science(MS) approach; constructing & solving OR&MS problems; OR&MS techniques; Break-even Analysis; Intro to Math Programming; Linear Programming;
learning_activities.topic_title: Introduction to OR & MS; Optimization and Math Programming
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to OR & MS; Optimization and Math Programming Operations Research (OR) & Management Science(MS) approach; constructing & solving OR&MS problems; OR&MS techniques; Break-even Analysis; Intro to Math Programming; Linear Programming;

learning_activities.topic:
Math Programming A

the graphical solution method for linear program (LP); characteristics of an LP problem; irregular problems; sensitivity analysis; examples
learning_activities.topic_description: Math Programming A the graphical solution method for linear program (LP); characteristics of an LP problem; irregular problems; sensitivity analysis; examples

learning_activities.topic:
Math Programming B

Sensitivity analysis; LP in matrix form; the primal and dual LP; duality theorem; integer and 0-1 programs; mixed programs;
learning_activities.topic_description: Math Programming B Sensitivity analysis; LP in matrix form; the primal and dual LP; duality theorem; integer and 0-1 programs; mixed programs;

learning_activities.topic:
Transportation Problems; Intro to Projects

Transportation and assignment problems. Key elements of project management; Gantt charts; CPM & PERT;
learning_activities.topic_description: Transportation Problems; Intro to Projects Transportation and assignment problems. Key elements of project management; Gantt charts; CPM & PERT;

learning_activities.topic:
Project Scheduling and Control

Project Scheduling and Control (Lecture): the project network; solution algorithms; Probability analysis of a project network; project crashing using CPM; estimating probabilities using PERT.
learning_activities.topic_description: Project Scheduling and Control Project Scheduling and Control (Lecture): the project network; solution algorithms; Probability analysis of a project network; project crashing using CPM; estimating probabilities using PERT.

learning_activities.topic:
Decision Theory A

terminology and notation of decision theory; the decision-making process and its components; criteria for decision making; decision-making with and without probabilities;
learning_activities.topic_description: Decision Theory A terminology and notation of decision theory; the decision-making process and its components; criteria for decision making; decision-making with and without probabilities;

learning_activities.topic:
Decision Analysis B

Bayesian analysis for accounting additional information; utility, different types of risk; basics of game theory
learning_activities.topic_description: Decision Analysis B Bayesian analysis for accounting additional information; utility, different types of risk; basics of game theory

learning_activities.topic:
Inventory Models

inventory terminology; notation; the basic EOQM; extensions to the basic EOQM.
learning_activities.topic_description: Inventory Models inventory terminology; notation; the basic EOQM; extensions to the basic EOQM.

learning_activities.topic:
Queueing Theory

modelling of the arrival process; the waiting line; modelling of the service process; transient and steady states; M/M/1 systems; M/M/k systems; other systems;
learning_activities.topic_description: Queueing Theory modelling of the arrival process; the waiting line; modelling of the service process; transient and steady states; M/M/1 systems; M/M/k systems; other systems;

learning_activities.topic:
Mid-Sem Break

No lecture or tutorial this week.
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid-Sem Break No lecture or tutorial this week.

Students who would normally attend tutorial on this day are advised to attend another session of the week, for this week only.

learning_activities.topic:
Production Analysis & Decisions A

Production Theory: profit, revenue, cost; profit efficiency, revenue efficiency, cost efficiency; various technical and allocative efficiency measures; Linear and integer programming problems of production: Data Envelopment Analysis and Free Disposal Hull Analysis;
learning_activities.topic_description: Production Analysis & Decisions A Production Theory: profit, revenue, cost; profit efficiency, revenue efficiency, cost efficiency; various technical and allocative efficiency measures; Linear and integer programming problems of production: Data Envelopment Analysis and Free Disposal Hull Analysis;

learning_activities.topic:
Production Analysis & Decisions B

Productivity Indexes: Theory and Practice; Estimating productivity indexes with DEA & FDH and via the index numbers approach.
learning_activities.topic_description: Production Analysis & Decisions B Productivity Indexes: Theory and Practice; Estimating productivity indexes with DEA & FDH and via the index numbers approach.

learning_activities.topic:
Review

Review of Lecture 1-12 and tips about the Project
